description: This exam has been retired. The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999. It was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining the Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) to provide the learner with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field
name: Network+

episodes.description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999. It was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining the Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) to provide the learner with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field
episodes.title: Overview of Network+

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don give a high level overview of the first objective of the Network+ exam. They detail the sub-objectives that will be covered in the 1.0 Networking Concepts objective such as the OSI model, classifying devices, IP addressing, ports and protocols, and more.
episodes.title: Networking Concepts Overview

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don take a look at the OSI model and its seven layers. They break down each layer while discussing the protocols that can be found there. They also talk about TCP/IP model and how it compares to the OSI model.
episodes.title: The OSI Model

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don classify the various devices, protocols and applications found on the network and how they relate to the OSI model.
episodes.title: Classifying Items In OSI

episodes.description: In this episode Don describes the characteristics of IP addressing. He begins with breaking down the IP address to binary conversion and how the subnet mask comes into play in determining which class the IP address belongs to. He wraps the show with a discussion on the main classes of IP addresses; both public and private classes.
episodes.title: IP Addressing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.046 --> 00:00:10.046
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15.045 --> 00:00:19.754
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22.171 --> 00:00:32.171
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33.796 --> 00:00:34.710
All right.

5
00:00:34.710 --> 00:00:36.620
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening and

6
00:00:36.620 --> 00:00:38.770
welcome back to another
episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:38.770 --> 00:00:43.879
I'm your host Don Pasette, back again
with another episode of CompTIA Network+.

8
00:00:43.879 --> 00:00:47.921
Today, we're gonna be taking a look
at exam objective 1.3, which is,

9
00:00:47.921 --> 00:00:51.660
explain the purpose and
properties of IP Addressing.

10
00:00:51.660 --> 00:00:55.410
Now, this is one of the more deceptive
exam objectives when you're looking

11
00:00:55.410 --> 00:00:56.320
at the list.

12
00:00:56.320 --> 00:00:58.390
If we just bring it up,
I'll bring it up here real quick.

13
00:00:58.390 --> 00:01:00.636
So far we've seen earlier
objectives like 1.1 and

14
00:01:00.636 --> 00:01:03.420
1.2 where they've got
a ton of stuff listed.

15
00:01:03.420 --> 00:01:05.150
And then we get to 1.3 and

16
00:01:05.150 --> 00:01:09.060
it really just looks like a couple
of points, nothing too crazy.

17
00:01:09.060 --> 00:01:11.120
But, there are a few of these,

18
00:01:11.120 --> 00:01:14.940
like this little guy right here,
that are actually some of the larger,

19
00:01:14.940 --> 00:01:19.120
and more difficult topics to grasp inside
of the network plus certification.

20
00:01:19.120 --> 00:01:22.080
So even though it looks like just a
handful of bullet points here in the exam

21
00:01:22.080 --> 00:01:25.270
objectives, we are spending
a good bit of time on this one.

22
00:01:25.270 --> 00:01:28.780
So this episode we're gonna
cover the basics, and

23
00:01:28.780 --> 00:01:31.810
then what we'll do is the second part of
this episode where we go more advanced

24
00:01:31.810 --> 00:01:35.660
into some of the difficult areas
of working with IP addresses.

25
00:01:36.660 --> 00:01:40.170
But, we can't get there unless
we cover the basics first.

26
00:01:40.170 --> 00:01:42.170
So, lets start with the basics.

27
00:01:42.170 --> 00:01:45.845
They are asking for us to understand the
purpose and properties of an IP address,

28
00:01:45.845 --> 00:01:49.830
so we probably need to know,
what is an IP address?

29
00:01:49.830 --> 00:01:51.840
Well, when you have a Network, and

30
00:01:51.840 --> 00:01:54.970
you have more than one computer on that
network, and you want them to talk to

31
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:58.410
each other, they've got to
have a way to find each other.

32
00:01:58.410 --> 00:02:00.730
How can they find each
other on the network?

33
00:02:00.730 --> 00:02:03.710
If there were only two
computers on the network,

34
00:02:03.710 --> 00:02:04.860
they wouldn't have to find each other.

35
00:02:04.860 --> 00:02:07.890
Just one person could shout and
the other person would hear them, right?

36
00:02:07.890 --> 00:02:08.740
Very easy.

37
00:02:08.740 --> 00:02:12.550
If you have two people in a room,
they don't have to see each other.

38
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:13.640
They can just talk out loud.

39
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:16.490
The other person is going to hear it and
they can have a conversation.

40
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:18.290
Well, that's how two computers would be.

41
00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:21.350
And in the earliest of networks,
that's how it was.

42
00:02:21.350 --> 00:02:24.210
You had two computers with
a cable that ran between them and

43
00:02:24.210 --> 00:02:26.370
they could just shout
right over that cable.

44
00:02:26.370 --> 00:02:28.570
You didn't need addressing.

45
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:32.930
But it wasn't long before people wanted
3 computers, or 4 computers, or 50,

46
00:02:32.930 --> 00:02:38.350
100 computers, and at that point
when you talk on the network,

47
00:02:38.350 --> 00:02:40.660
did you want to talk to everybody?

48
00:02:40.660 --> 00:02:43.580
Not normally, normally you
wanted to talk to one person, so

49
00:02:43.580 --> 00:02:45.590
you had to have some way to find them.

50
00:02:45.590 --> 00:02:47.290
Now the early networks didn't do that.

51
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:52.000
So when you take a look at older networks
like token ring, and some of the thin net,

52
00:02:52.000 --> 00:02:57.030
thick net, those guys back then, even they
didn't use addressing in the early days.

53
00:02:57.030 --> 00:03:00.430
You would throw stuff on the wire and
everyone would hear it.

54
00:03:00.430 --> 00:03:03.040
And some computers would see that
information you were sending and

55
00:03:03.040 --> 00:03:05.360
act on it, and
other people would just ignore it.

56
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:06.985
It wasn't very efficient.

57
00:03:06.985 --> 00:03:09.635
And those networks
couldn't scale very large.

58
00:03:09.635 --> 00:03:13.135
So, we had to come up with some way,
I say we like I was involved.

59
00:03:13.135 --> 00:03:17.535
They the people that designed IP
addressing, they had to come up with a way

60
00:03:17.535 --> 00:03:21.645
to identify machines uniquely,
so that when you talked,

61
00:03:21.645 --> 00:03:25.065
you weren't talking to everybody, you
were talking to one person specifically.

62
00:03:25.065 --> 00:03:29.000
And they were planning for
the networks of the future.

63
00:03:29.000 --> 00:03:32.360
Well, this was 40 years ago,
and here we are today, and

64
00:03:32.360 --> 00:03:34.310
we're in that network of the future.

65
00:03:34.310 --> 00:03:38.930
When you look at the internet,
you have millions of computers across

66
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:42.130
the world that are all interconnected,
and able to talk to each other.

67
00:03:42.130 --> 00:03:46.160
Could you imagine if we still followed the
old method, where you just shouted out and

68
00:03:46.160 --> 00:03:47.421
everybody had to listen?

69
00:03:47.421 --> 00:03:52.150
With millions of computers out there doing
that, it would be constant collisions and

70
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:53.650
a bandwidth nightmare.

71
00:03:53.650 --> 00:03:55.080
It wouldn't work.

72
00:03:55.080 --> 00:03:57.171
Networks like the Internet
would not be possible.

73
00:03:57.171 --> 00:04:01.200
All right, so
IP addressing is what fills that gap.

74
00:04:01.200 --> 00:04:03.050
It's what makes it possible.

75
00:04:03.050 --> 00:04:05.070
An IP address is simply a number.

76
00:04:05.070 --> 00:04:09.620
It's a number attached to each computer
on a network that identifies it.

77
00:04:09.620 --> 00:04:13.360
And IP specifically,
that stands for Internet Protocol.

78
00:04:13.360 --> 00:04:14.922
It was designed for the Internet.

79
00:04:14.922 --> 00:04:17.665
But it didn't take long for

80
00:04:17.665 --> 00:04:23.790
people to recognize that it
was a really good protocol.

81
00:04:23.790 --> 00:04:29.480
And over the last 30 years, we've seen
many other addressing schemes come and

82
00:04:29.480 --> 00:04:34.090
go, and IP addressing has
settled in as the standard.

83
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:37.260
So in today's world when
you go to a network,

84
00:04:37.260 --> 00:04:39.900
the odds are it's gonna
be an IP based network.

85
00:04:39.900 --> 00:04:42.940
In fact it's pretty rare
that you spot anything else.

86
00:04:42.940 --> 00:04:46.620
So on the exam, they don't even
focus on the other guys anymore.

87
00:04:46.620 --> 00:04:50.830
Technologies like AppleTalk,
IPX/SPX, Banyan VINES,

88
00:04:50.830 --> 00:04:55.860
these technologies used to be big,
back in the late 80s, early 90s even,

89
00:04:55.860 --> 00:05:00.330
but by this time, all right,
20 years later, they're nonexistent.

90
00:05:00.330 --> 00:05:02.770
You really don't see networks
running those protocols anymore.

91
00:05:02.770 --> 00:05:05.960
So IP addressing is what you're
going to see on the Internet and

92
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:07.710
in your private networks.

93
00:05:07.710 --> 00:05:10.930
All right, so I mentioned that
an IP address is like a number.

94
00:05:10.930 --> 00:05:12.620
It is, it's a number.

95
00:05:12.620 --> 00:05:17.530
And it's made up of two parts,
one part identifies your network,

96
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:22.910
the network that you're on, and the other
part identifies you, your computer.

97
00:05:22.910 --> 00:05:26.490
Those two parts work very
similar to a street address.

98
00:05:26.490 --> 00:05:29.260
Let's put the technology side
out of our minds for a moment,

99
00:05:29.260 --> 00:05:32.520
and let me just kind of
show you an example here.

100
00:05:32.520 --> 00:05:35.490
So the building I'm in right now.

101
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:43.220
I'm at the ITPro TV studios, and
we are at 6933 NW 4th Boulevard, right?

102
00:05:43.220 --> 00:05:46.180
That's the street address for
our building.

103
00:05:46.180 --> 00:05:50.540
So if you wanted to come and visit
the studio, you could go into your GPS and

104
00:05:50.540 --> 00:05:51.530
you could punch in that.

105
00:05:51.530 --> 00:05:56.160
Now, if you were in the same city as me,
you'd know exactly where to get that,

106
00:05:56.160 --> 00:05:57.320
your GPS would find it.

107
00:05:57.320 --> 00:05:59.550
But if you're in a different city,
or even a different country,

108
00:05:59.550 --> 00:06:02.370
you might need a little more information.

109
00:06:02.370 --> 00:06:04.520
But IP addresses are smarter then that.

110
00:06:04.520 --> 00:06:07.760
They can be a lot more complex, and
so we don't have the other things,

111
00:06:07.760 --> 00:06:14.230
we don't need a city, a state,
a zip code, a country, right?

112
00:06:14.230 --> 00:06:17.760
We don't need all of that other stuff
because IP addresses manage to wrap

113
00:06:17.760 --> 00:06:21.020
this all up inside of
one bit of the address.

114
00:06:22.330 --> 00:06:25.810
Now this street address,
it's made up of two parts.

115
00:06:25.810 --> 00:06:30.260
The first part, 6933,
that's my building number, right?

116
00:06:30.260 --> 00:06:32.540
So that is my building number.

117
00:06:32.540 --> 00:06:37.710
And on this street,
there is no other building that's 6933.

118
00:06:37.710 --> 00:06:40.810
There's a 6934 and a 6932.

119
00:06:40.810 --> 00:06:43.337
There's probably a couple of other
numbers thrown in there just

120
00:06:43.337 --> 00:06:45.462
with the other buildings
that are here on the street.

121
00:06:45.462 --> 00:06:50.754
But we are the only 6933 on this street,
right?

122
00:06:50.754 --> 00:06:57.220
Northwest 4th Boulevard,
That is our street name.

123
00:06:58.900 --> 00:07:00.900
And in our city,

124
00:07:00.900 --> 00:07:04.560
in the city of Gainesville,
that is the only Northwest 4th Boulevard.

125
00:07:04.560 --> 00:07:06.923
There is no other Northwest
4th Boulevard in town.

126
00:07:06.923 --> 00:07:09.990
There might be a Southwest or
a Northeast or whatever.

127
00:07:09.990 --> 00:07:12.390
There's only one Northwest 4th Boulevard.

128
00:07:12.390 --> 00:07:16.430
All right, so,
this street is unique to our

129
00:07:18.210 --> 00:07:20.960
city, 6933 is only unique to the street,
right?

130
00:07:20.960 --> 00:07:22.379
There might be other 6933's.

131
00:07:22.379 --> 00:07:25.370
There might be a 6933
Northwest 5th Boulevard.

132
00:07:25.370 --> 00:07:27.180
That doesn't bump into me, right?

133
00:07:27.180 --> 00:07:31.300
So the two parts of this address by
themselves, are not necessarily unique.

134
00:07:31.300 --> 00:07:34.360
There's other buildings in
town that might be 6933,

135
00:07:34.360 --> 00:07:36.930
and there are other streets in town,
or other buildings,

136
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:40.390
sorry there's other buildings on my street
that end in Northwest 4th Boulevard.

137
00:07:40.390 --> 00:07:46.780
So those get reused, but together it's
unique and it identifies our building.

138
00:07:46.780 --> 00:07:48.540
No other building in
the city of Gainesville

139
00:07:48.540 --> 00:07:50.740
is 6933 Northwest 4th Boulevard.

140
00:07:50.740 --> 00:07:52.084
That's how an IP address is.

141
00:07:52.084 --> 00:07:57.125
The IP address has those two pieces
that kind of fit this same model,

142
00:07:57.125 --> 00:07:59.168
only they look different.

143
00:07:59.168 --> 00:08:04.459
For example 192.168.01.

144
00:08:04.459 --> 00:08:09.214
That is an example of an IPv4 address.

145
00:08:09.214 --> 00:08:17.330
And part of it, 192.168.0,
is the Network ID.

146
00:08:17.330 --> 00:08:23.930
And the other part,
which is just .1, is the Host ID.

147
00:08:23.930 --> 00:08:29.080
So 192.168.0 identifies
the network that it's on.

148
00:08:29.080 --> 00:08:31.010
That network is shared by other computers,

149
00:08:31.010 --> 00:08:33.320
this is other computers
on that same network.

150
00:08:33.320 --> 00:08:36.990
But .1, that's the Host ID,
on that network,

151
00:08:36.990 --> 00:08:39.980
this computer is the only
one that ends in .1.

152
00:08:39.980 --> 00:08:42.220
Nobody else on this network does.

153
00:08:42.220 --> 00:08:45.310
Somebody might be on a different network,
and they may end in .1.

154
00:08:45.310 --> 00:08:49.070
Sure, it's a different network, but
on my network, it's me individually.

155
00:08:50.710 --> 00:08:54.420
So these two things combined,
the Network ID and the Host ID,

156
00:08:54.420 --> 00:08:56.990
when you stick them together.

157
00:08:56.990 --> 00:09:01.920
So if we say NetworkID.HostID When
we stick those together,

158
00:09:01.920 --> 00:09:06.680
that becomes a unique identifier for
my machine.

159
00:09:06.680 --> 00:09:09.810
It says, that's me and
that's how you can find me.

160
00:09:09.810 --> 00:09:12.720
So if you wanna get to me specifically,
here's how you do it.

161
00:09:14.560 --> 00:09:22.650
Just like up here, where we have our
BuildingNumber and our StreetName.

162
00:09:22.650 --> 00:09:25.370
Those two combine to
create that unique value.

163
00:09:25.370 --> 00:09:27.720
That is what an IP address is.

164
00:09:27.720 --> 00:09:32.600
Now I mentioned how in a street name or
whatever

165
00:09:32.600 --> 00:09:38.030
that we may have to also include a city
and a state and a country and a zip code.

166
00:09:38.030 --> 00:09:43.700
Because there's so many NW 4th
Blvds across the United States,

167
00:09:43.700 --> 00:09:46.480
and there's so
many of those across the State of Florida.

168
00:09:46.480 --> 00:09:50.610
So we've gotta be able to kinda
direct that down to a smaller area.

169
00:09:50.610 --> 00:09:53.710
But with IP addressing,
because this is a number,

170
00:09:53.710 --> 00:09:58.790
there are literally millions of
different options that this could be and

171
00:09:58.790 --> 00:10:01.860
since there's so many different options,
we don't have duplicates.

172
00:10:01.860 --> 00:10:03.560
We don't have to worry about that so

173
00:10:03.560 --> 00:10:07.070
we don't need those additional
identifiers to get us to the target.

174
00:10:07.070 --> 00:10:10.720
But, at its heart,
that's what an IP address is.

175
00:10:10.720 --> 00:10:13.230
And when you get on your computer and

176
00:10:13.230 --> 00:10:17.090
you hop out on the internet,
You're getting an address like that.

177
00:10:17.090 --> 00:10:18.040
You may never see it.

178
00:10:18.040 --> 00:10:20.760
You may never even noticed it before,
but you have one.

179
00:10:20.760 --> 00:10:24.560
The fact that you're on this website,
watching this episode right now, or

180
00:10:24.560 --> 00:10:26.940
on your Roku watching
this episode right now.

181
00:10:26.940 --> 00:10:30.300
Either way, you're on the internet
to be able to get to us,

182
00:10:30.300 --> 00:10:32.350
and that means you have an address.

183
00:10:32.350 --> 00:10:34.410
You can see it, you can fire up a website.

184
00:10:35.540 --> 00:10:39.064
I use a few different websites, but
one of them I like is ipmonkey.com.

185
00:10:40.120 --> 00:10:41.213
Just because it's got a funny name.

186
00:10:41.213 --> 00:10:43.994
If you go to IPMonkey.com,
a little monkey appears and

187
00:10:43.994 --> 00:10:46.255
he tells you exactly
what your IP address is.

188
00:10:46.255 --> 00:10:47.589
There's my IP address.

189
00:10:47.589 --> 00:10:51.339
209.251.159.179.

190
00:10:51.339 --> 00:10:53.870
That's me.

191
00:10:53.870 --> 00:10:58.940
No one else in the entire planet is
using that IP address right now.

192
00:10:58.940 --> 00:11:00.390
That's me.

193
00:11:01.480 --> 00:11:04.380
If you got a thing against monkeys,
you can always use IP Chicken also.

194
00:11:04.380 --> 00:11:07.680
We like to keep our varieties open,
so I'll go to IPChicken.com, and

195
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:12.130
I'll see that here we go again,
209.251.159.179.

196
00:11:12.130 --> 00:11:14.270
And apparently it thinks I'm in Denver.

197
00:11:14.270 --> 00:11:16.630
So [LAUGH] no that's
advertising with Google.

198
00:11:17.950 --> 00:11:18.850
So there we go.

199
00:11:18.850 --> 00:11:20.290
That's our IP address.

200
00:11:20.290 --> 00:11:21.000
That's us.

201
00:11:21.000 --> 00:11:21.790
That's us on the network.

202
00:11:21.790 --> 00:11:23.300
And you're watching this show right now.

203
00:11:23.300 --> 00:11:26.580
You hit pause or if it's live I
guess you can't really do that, but

204
00:11:26.580 --> 00:11:28.468
open up another window and
do exactly what I did.

205
00:11:28.468 --> 00:11:31.290
Go to WhatIsMyIP.com or IPmonkey or

206
00:11:31.290 --> 00:11:34.510
IPchicken, all these different sites
that are out there that do this.

207
00:11:34.510 --> 00:11:36.180
I used to always use WhatIsMyIP.com but

208
00:11:36.180 --> 00:11:38.000
they started doing too
many ads on their page.

209
00:11:38.000 --> 00:11:40.660
Well, actually they might
have cleaned it up a bit.

210
00:11:40.660 --> 00:11:42.190
But either way, you'll jump out there and

211
00:11:42.190 --> 00:11:46.640
see what your IP address is to
get an idea of what that is.

212
00:11:46.640 --> 00:11:48.630
That's your unique identifier.

213
00:11:48.630 --> 00:11:50.810
The only problem is when
you look at that number,

214
00:11:50.810 --> 00:11:54.140
do you know which part is your network and
which part is your host?

215
00:11:54.140 --> 00:11:56.270

the placeholders and all that stuff.

00:37:29.450 --> 00:37:30.510
These are really easy.

679
00:37:30.510 --> 00:37:34.220
255 should be one of the ones that
you have committed to memory.

680
00:37:34.220 --> 00:37:42.019
A 255 is eight 1s, and then a 0 is
simply eight 0s, and there's my 32 bits.

681
00:37:42.019 --> 00:37:46.560
If I were to add up all those 1s and 0s,
there's actually 32 digits, right here,

682
00:37:46.560 --> 00:37:49.480
not counting the periods,
the periods don't count.

683
00:37:50.680 --> 00:37:52.980
But there's those three subnets, and

684
00:37:52.980 --> 00:37:57.730
what we can see is that the ones
are always on the left.

685
00:37:57.730 --> 00:38:00.500
See how the ones are always
over on the left, and

686
00:38:00.500 --> 00:38:02.850
the zeros are always on the right.

687
00:38:02.850 --> 00:38:06.860
In a subnet mask, the ones and
zeroes never mix.

688
00:38:06.860 --> 00:38:08.310
They don't mix together.

689
00:38:08.310 --> 00:38:13.210
Because it's showing us
the particular point at which

690
00:38:13.210 --> 00:38:18.430
the network ID stops,
and the host ID starts.

691
00:38:18.430 --> 00:38:21.110
So when you give me an address,
like this, 172.143.8.16,

692
00:38:21.110 --> 00:38:26.380
these ones show me where that stops.

693
00:38:27.720 --> 00:38:30.130
If I gave you this subnet mask right here,
255.0.0.0,

694
00:38:30.130 --> 00:38:33.910
that means the 172 is the network and
143.8.16 is the host,

695
00:38:33.910 --> 00:38:37.850
it's the computer.

696
00:38:42.120 --> 00:38:42.670
All right.

697
00:38:42.670 --> 00:38:46.300
So that's where I'm getting that
street and building number.

698
00:38:46.300 --> 00:38:48.316
Right?
172 is the street and

699
00:38:48.316 --> 00:38:51.357
there's a lot of people on that street.

700
00:38:51.357 --> 00:38:56.660
And then 143.8.16,
that's my computer and that's just me.

701
00:38:56.660 --> 00:38:57.610
All right?

702
00:38:57.610 --> 00:39:00.030
Now, why do we need to know all this?

703
00:39:00.030 --> 00:39:05.150
Well, if I have two computers
that are on the same network,

704
00:39:05.150 --> 00:39:08.900
if I have two computers in this scenario,
would this be my subnet?

705
00:39:08.900 --> 00:39:13.180
If I have two computers who's IP addresses
start with 172 that means they're on

706
00:39:13.180 --> 00:39:19.180
the same network and they can talk
to each other directly, all right.

707
00:39:19.180 --> 00:39:22.730
But if they were on different networks.

708
00:39:22.730 --> 00:39:28.220
If one of them was on 172 and another
one was on 173, two different networks.

709
00:39:28.220 --> 00:39:30.700
Then they can't talk to
each other directly.

710
00:39:30.700 --> 00:39:33.730
Instead, they have to go through a router.

711
00:39:33.730 --> 00:39:36.490
A router will help you
get to other networks,

712
00:39:36.490 --> 00:39:38.290
networks that you're not connected to.

713
00:39:38.290 --> 00:39:39.570
Think about it as if you were at home.

714
00:39:39.570 --> 00:39:42.040
You know,
if you're at home watching the show,

715
00:39:42.040 --> 00:39:47.280
you've probably got a cable
high-speed Internet or DSL broadband.

716
00:39:47.280 --> 00:39:49.730
You might have satellite Internet or,
who knows,

717
00:39:49.730 --> 00:39:52.980
maybe you got fiber optic Metro-E
run into your house, or whatever.

718
00:39:52.980 --> 00:39:56.600
Well you have a network
inside of your house.

719
00:39:56.600 --> 00:39:59.983
And the computers in your house can
talk to each other without going to

720
00:39:59.983 --> 00:40:00.751
the Internet.

721
00:40:00.751 --> 00:40:03.618
But when they want to talk to the
Internet, they know to go to the router,

722
00:40:03.618 --> 00:40:06.210
to go out and connect to the bigger
network out there in the world.

723
00:40:06.210 --> 00:40:08.730
And they're doing that
thanks to your subnet mask.

724
00:40:08.730 --> 00:40:12.736
Your subnet mask is helping them
know when somebody is local and

725
00:40:12.736 --> 00:40:14.410
when somebody is remote.

726
00:40:14.410 --> 00:40:18.020
That's an important part of an IP address.

727
00:40:18.020 --> 00:40:22.692
Now if my subnet mask was 255.255.0.0,

728
00:40:22.692 --> 00:40:26.409
that would mean the first 16 bits here,

729
00:40:26.409 --> 00:40:31.490
the first 2 octets would
be part of the network ID.

730
00:40:31.490 --> 00:40:37.600
And with this address that means that
172.143 would be the network and

731
00:40:37.600 --> 00:40:39.858
8.16 would be the host.

732
00:40:39.858 --> 00:40:42.880
So if I had two computers
that started with 172.143,

733
00:40:42.880 --> 00:40:46.690
they could talk to each other
without going through a router.

734
00:40:46.690 --> 00:40:47.767
But if somebody was 172.144,

735
00:40:47.767 --> 00:40:53.490
we'd have to go through a router to
get to them, it's a different network.

736
00:40:53.490 --> 00:40:58.807
And it gets even smaller when we
get down here to 255.255.255.0.

737
00:40:58.807 --> 00:41:06.710
That means the first 3 octets, the first
24 bits are part of the network ID.

738
00:41:06.710 --> 00:41:13.540
That means that 172.143.8 is the network,
and .16 is me.

739
00:41:13.540 --> 00:41:17.110
So anybody else who starts with 172.143.8,

740
00:41:17.110 --> 00:41:19.130
I can talk to them without
going through a router.

741
00:41:19.130 --> 00:41:22.450
But anybody else, I'm gonna have to
go through my router to get there.

742
00:41:22.450 --> 00:41:25.030
All right, that's how routers work.

743
00:41:25.030 --> 00:41:27.840
They recognize networks
based on subnet masks and

744
00:41:27.840 --> 00:41:30.200
that's how our computers or clients work.

745
00:41:30.200 --> 00:41:32.310
They know when they can go direct,

746
00:41:32.310 --> 00:41:36.520
versus having to go through
a router based on this subnet mask.

747
00:41:36.520 --> 00:41:39.770
So subnet mask is really important, right?

748
00:41:39.770 --> 00:41:44.030
Now when IP addresses
were originally created,

749
00:41:44.030 --> 00:41:46.380
computer networks were very small, right?

750
00:41:46.380 --> 00:41:49.800
It was uncommon to have a network
with more than ten computers.

751
00:41:49.800 --> 00:41:53.850
And the idea of a global network spanning
millions of computers was just a dream in

752
00:41:53.850 --> 00:41:55.570
a sci fi writer's mind.

753
00:41:55.570 --> 00:41:59.620
And so
networks really have exploded since then.

754
00:41:59.620 --> 00:42:02.590
But in the early days,
they didn't plan for it that way.

755
00:42:02.590 --> 00:42:04.670
They planned for
things to be much smaller and

756
00:42:04.670 --> 00:42:09.440
so they didn't have subnet
masks in the very early days.

757
00:42:09.440 --> 00:42:13.618
In the very early days they used
something different called classes.

758
00:42:13.618 --> 00:42:18.240
IP addresses fell into certain classes,
and based on their numbers

759
00:42:18.240 --> 00:42:23.040
that's what would determine whether
certain values were the network ID or

760
00:42:23.040 --> 00:42:24.970
certain values were the host ID.

761
00:42:24.970 --> 00:42:29.580
And so we need to understand those
classes, they're not used anymore, right?

762
00:42:29.580 --> 00:42:33.350
We really don't use the classes, but
you'll hear people refer to them and

763
00:42:33.350 --> 00:42:36.560
it's more of just kind of throw
back to the old terminology, but

764
00:42:36.560 --> 00:42:38.380
on the exam, even,
you'll see them thrown out.

765
00:42:38.380 --> 00:42:40.930
So we need to remember those old classes.

766
00:42:40.930 --> 00:42:44.380
But on newer systems,
the classes don't matter.

767
00:42:44.380 --> 00:42:46.710
The subnet mask does all the work.

768
00:42:46.710 --> 00:42:48.430
So we're going to look at
that subnet mask more.

769
00:42:48.430 --> 00:42:51.370
We're actually going to do a special
episode just on subnetting,

770
00:42:51.370 --> 00:42:53.250
which is manipulating that subnet mask.

771
00:42:53.250 --> 00:42:55.220
So we'll get a chance to see that but

772
00:42:55.220 --> 00:42:57.610
these three right here
are really the most common.

773
00:42:57.610 --> 00:43:02.260
These are the ones you're gonna see on
a regular basis in private networks, and

774
00:43:02.260 --> 00:43:06.920
they're really easy to use because
255 means that whole octet.

775
00:43:06.920 --> 00:43:08.520
I really didn't have to convert to binary.

776
00:43:08.520 --> 00:43:12.600
I did it, right, I converted to binary
just to show it, but I didn't have to.

777
00:43:12.600 --> 00:43:14.940
I could have just said, well 255.255,

778
00:43:14.940 --> 00:43:19.030
that means the first two octets,
there's my network ID, done, right?

779
00:43:19.030 --> 00:43:21.160
And that's perfect, that's really ideal.

780
00:43:22.330 --> 00:43:25.560
But there's many other subnet
masks that can be used,

781
00:43:25.560 --> 00:43:28.870
these are just the three simplest,
simplest being the most common.

782
00:43:29.950 --> 00:43:31.440
Now these simplest ones,

783
00:43:31.440 --> 00:43:35.760
they actually correspond to the old
classes that I was talking about.

784
00:43:35.760 --> 00:43:37.810
They didn't make these
numbers up out of nowhere.

785
00:43:37.810 --> 00:43:40.660
These numbers built off
of the old classes.

786
00:43:40.660 --> 00:43:44.180
And there's some kind of neat
stuff there that we'll see.

787
00:43:44.180 --> 00:43:52.381
Let's take a look at those classes.

788
00:43:52.381 --> 00:43:53.072
With an IP address,
the absolute lowest number

789
00:43:53.072 --> 00:43:53.599
that we can have with an IP address.

790
00:43:55.120 --> 00:44:00.469
If we break this down in terms of
the lowest and highest number, okay.

791
00:44:00.469 --> 00:44:07.388
With a 32-bit decimal number,
binary number, sorry,

792
00:44:07.388 --> 00:44:13.370
32-bit binary number, the lowest number
you could have would be 32 zeroes, okay.

793
00:44:13.370 --> 00:44:16.200
And I'm gonna cheat just a little
bit to save me some typing.

794
00:44:18.320 --> 00:44:23.480
So, the lowest number we could
have would be 32 0s like that,

795
00:44:23.480 --> 00:44:27.820
and really, in binary,
we would drop those dots out.

796
00:44:27.820 --> 00:44:30.010
So, it's really just 32 0s.

797
00:44:30.010 --> 00:44:32.790
Fortunately for us that is
something really easy to convert,

798
00:44:32.790 --> 00:44:35.660
because all zeros is a zero, right?

799
00:44:35.660 --> 00:44:42.150
Super easy, but, the highest number
that we could have, would be 32 1s.

800
00:44:42.150 --> 00:44:48.670
32 1s would be the absolute highest number
that we could have in a 32 bit value.

801
00:44:48.670 --> 00:44:53.320
And in IPv4, that actually works
out to a much bigger number.

802
00:44:54.640 --> 00:44:57.300
All right, so there's the 32.

803
00:44:57.300 --> 00:45:01.054
So, when we go to convert a number
like this, it's huge, and

804
00:45:01.054 --> 00:45:06.270
the number that we're gonna result in, is
the total size of the IPv4 address space.

805
00:45:06.270 --> 00:45:07.328
So let me just write that here.

806
00:45:07.328 --> 00:45:12.929
It's 4,294,967,

807
00:45:12.929 --> 00:45:21.444
oh, wait, 4,294,967,296.

808
00:45:21.444 --> 00:45:25.310
That is the highest number we can
write in a 32 bit address space.

809
00:45:25.310 --> 00:45:31.724
So, that means, whoever created IPv4,
or IP as we know it, originally,

810
00:45:31.724 --> 00:45:39.275
they picked a 32-bit address that only
supported roughly 4.3 billion addresses.

811
00:45:39.275 --> 00:45:41.140
Well, how may people are in the world?

812
00:45:42.340 --> 00:45:43.740
A lot more than 4.3 billion.

813
00:45:43.740 --> 00:45:46.849
I think the world's population is
creeping up on 7 billion now, so

814
00:45:46.849 --> 00:45:48.930
it's getting to be pretty large.

815
00:45:48.930 --> 00:45:53.090
So these IP addresses are not
really the be all end all.

816
00:45:53.090 --> 00:45:56.530
And we're gonna see later on
that there's a newer version

817
00:45:56.530 --> 00:45:59.160
of IP that's kind of replacing this.

818
00:45:59.160 --> 00:46:05.150
What we're seeing here, this is called
IPv4, or Internet Protocol version four.

819
00:46:05.150 --> 00:46:08.320
There really wasn't a version one,
two, or three, they weren't released.

820
00:46:08.320 --> 00:46:11.510
Version four was the one that was
publicly released that we all use.

821
00:46:11.510 --> 00:46:15.790
And it's the most common version
of internet protocols available.

822
00:46:15.790 --> 00:46:19.790
The replacement for it is IPv6,
Internet Protocol Version 6.

823
00:46:19.790 --> 00:46:25.540
They skipped 5, there was some kind of a
trademark dispute with that IPv5 moniker.

824
00:46:25.540 --> 00:46:28.369
But IPv6 is what the newer one is, and

825
00:46:28.369 --> 00:46:33.243
it goes to a 128 bit address base,
which is insanely massive.

826
00:46:33.243 --> 00:46:36.570
It is a gigantic one because it
doesn't have a 32-bit number.

827
00:46:36.570 --> 00:46:39.070
It's got a 128-bit number.

828
00:46:39.070 --> 00:46:41.470
That's insanely large.

829
00:46:41.470 --> 00:46:43.380
We'll talk about it in another segment.

830
00:46:43.380 --> 00:46:45.620
Let's save that one for later.

831
00:46:45.620 --> 00:46:49.840
But when we represent the full numbers
like this, those are some big numbers.

832
00:46:51.140 --> 00:46:54.310
But if we just deal
with individual octets.

833
00:46:54.310 --> 00:46:56.650
When we look at just
the individual octets,

834
00:46:56.650 --> 00:46:59.430
the numbers become a lot more manageable.

835
00:46:59.430 --> 00:47:01.610
An individual octet's only eight bits.

836
00:47:03.170 --> 00:47:06.660
So the lowest number we
could write is a 0, and

837
00:47:06.660 --> 00:47:11.840
the highest number we could write
would be 8 1s, which is 255.

838
00:47:11.840 --> 00:47:18.080
So when you're dealing with individual
octets, just that makes it easy.

839
00:47:18.080 --> 00:47:20.380
No numbers higher than 255.

840
00:47:20.380 --> 00:47:22.380
Nothing more than eight digits in binary.

841
00:47:22.380 --> 00:47:23.710
Pretty simple to convert.

842
00:47:23.710 --> 00:47:25.112
So that's kind of our saving grace here.

843
00:47:25.112 --> 00:47:29.680
As we start to convert these numbers,
life becomes a lot easier, all right?

844
00:47:29.680 --> 00:47:31.620
Okay, but I mentioned the classes.

845
00:47:31.620 --> 00:47:35.140
Now the classes are gonna
take this address space.

846
00:47:35.140 --> 00:47:40.582
It's gonna take these 4.3 billion
addresses, and it's gonna divide them up.

847
00:47:40.582 --> 00:47:44.160
It's gonna divide them up into
smaller units, which is what

848
00:47:44.160 --> 00:47:48.510
made it possible to give some people IP's,
and other people other IP's.

849
00:47:48.510 --> 00:47:52.002
In the early days of the Internet, you had
to go out and get IP addresses to use, and

850
00:47:52.002 --> 00:47:54.293
you didn't want to duplicate anybody else,
right?

851
00:47:54.293 --> 00:47:58.734
If you have a duplicate with somebody,
it's gonna cause all sorts of problems,

852
00:47:58.734 --> 00:48:01.751
and that's why everyone has
to have a unique address.

853
00:48:01.751 --> 00:48:04.252
Well, how do we keep that straight?

854
00:48:04.252 --> 00:48:08.000
Fortunately for us, there is actually
an organization that takes care of that.

855
00:48:08.000 --> 00:48:12.244
There's an organization called the IANA.

856
00:48:12.244 --> 00:48:16.850
The IANA which is
the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority.

857
00:48:16.850 --> 00:48:20.850
This is the organization that
manages the IPV4 address space.

858
00:48:20.850 --> 00:48:25.200
If you wanna get on the Internet you're
going to need an IP address, and that IP

859
00:48:25.200 --> 00:48:31.400
address is going to have to be given to
you either directly by the IANA, which

860
00:48:31.400 --> 00:48:36.920
is pretty uncommon, or more commonly from
your ISP, your Internet Service Provider.

861
00:48:36.920 --> 00:48:40.410
So my Internet Service Provider
here is a company called GRU.

862
00:48:40.410 --> 00:48:45.232
GRU has an upstream provider, they buy
their bandwidth from somebody else, and

863
00:48:45.232 --> 00:48:47.100
their upstream provider is Cogent.

864
00:48:47.100 --> 00:48:51.708
And Cogent Communications, they're big,
they are a massive company and

865
00:48:51.708 --> 00:48:54.720
they buy their addresses from the IANA,
right?

866
00:48:54.720 --> 00:48:55.330
They get them from the top.

867
00:48:55.330 --> 00:48:59.215
Well, actually, there's one extra tier
in there I'll talk about in a minute.

868
00:48:59.215 --> 00:49:01.720
But basically they come from the IANA.

869
00:49:01.720 --> 00:49:03.820
So the IANA doesn't normally
deal with little people,

870
00:49:03.820 --> 00:49:05.230
they don't deal with people like me.

871
00:49:05.230 --> 00:49:07.440
I've never bought an address
right from the IANA,

872
00:49:07.440 --> 00:49:09.600
even though they manage it, all right?

873
00:49:09.600 --> 00:49:13.680
Instead they dole them out to other
organizations that in turn dole them out

874
00:49:13.680 --> 00:49:15.250
to customers like me.

875
00:49:15.250 --> 00:49:18.350
So that's where our addresses
are coming from, and

876
00:49:18.350 --> 00:49:19.960
the IANA is trying to manage that.

877
00:49:19.960 --> 00:49:23.850
And in the early days,
they managed it by creating these classes,

878
00:49:23.850 --> 00:49:29.640
these subdivisions of IPs, to cut them
into pieces that can be given out.

879
00:49:29.640 --> 00:49:32.030
And so when you requested an address,

880
00:49:32.030 --> 00:49:34.110
there were three classes
you could request.

881
00:49:34.110 --> 00:49:38.281
A class A, a class B, or a class C.

882
00:49:38.281 --> 00:49:44.890
A class A would give you
16.7 million IP addresses.

883
00:49:44.890 --> 00:49:49.510
So if you needed a bunch of
IP's you'd go to the IANA and

884
00:49:49.510 --> 00:49:50.620
say hey can I have a class A?

885
00:49:50.620 --> 00:49:55.000
And they'd say sure here you go here
is 16.7 million IP's, good luck.

886
00:49:55.000 --> 00:49:59.200
And now you could bring up a network with
16.7 million computers and you'd be fine.

887
00:49:59.200 --> 00:50:02.460
All right, now you might ask
yourself who the heck would do that?

888
00:50:02.460 --> 00:50:03.970
Plenty of companies did, right?

889
00:50:03.970 --> 00:50:06.070
Ford motor company did it.

890
00:50:06.070 --> 00:50:09.860
This was back in the late 70s,
early 80s, and Ford said,

891
00:50:09.860 --> 00:50:13.370
hey we don't know about this Internet
thing, but it might catch on, and

892
00:50:13.370 --> 00:50:18.200
if it does, we might want every one
of our cars to have an IP address.

893
00:50:18.200 --> 00:50:21.440
We better get in on that early,
let's get those IPs.

894
00:50:21.440 --> 00:50:24.163
And they got a pool of 16.7 million IPs.

895
00:50:24.163 --> 00:50:27.781
Now as time went on, they didn't need it,
and so they gave it back, right, but

896
00:50:27.781 --> 00:50:30.420
they did have that pool originally.

897
00:50:30.420 --> 00:50:32.580
Apple computer, they said well, shoot,

898
00:50:32.580 --> 00:50:34.500
we might want to include
an IP with every computer.

899
00:50:34.500 --> 00:50:40.320
So they requested a class A and got 16.7
million IPs which they still hold today.

900
00:50:40.320 --> 00:50:45.420
Right now at this very moment Apple has
over 16.7 million IPs and for those of

901
00:50:45.420 --> 00:50:48.730
you who know there's an Internet shortage
out there, there' actually an IP shortage.

902
00:50:48.730 --> 00:50:51.560
People have been putting pressure on Apple
