590
00:31:34.440 --> 00:31:39.332
People who opt in, people who
are listening on special addresses and

591
00:31:39.332 --> 00:31:43.730
multicast addresses are really
easy to spot inside of IPv6.

592
00:31:43.730 --> 00:31:46.940
Because they start with it,

593
00:31:46.940 --> 00:31:52.168
they start with FF0, well really just FF0.

594
00:31:52.168 --> 00:31:58.708
[LAUGH] There's a few different ranges but
FF0 is where they start and it is.

595
00:31:58.708 --> 00:32:00.419
Actually I'll write it as FF00.

596
00:32:00.419 --> 00:32:02.168
Okay I gotta get my placeholder in there.

597
00:32:02.168 --> 00:32:04.762
You can leave off leading
zeros at the beginning but

598
00:32:04.762 --> 00:32:06.700
you can't leave off trailing zeros.

599
00:32:06.700 --> 00:32:10.150
You gotta leave those, but it is a /8.

600
00:32:10.150 --> 00:32:15.530
And what that means, that /8, means that
it's really just the first eight bits.

601
00:32:15.530 --> 00:32:20.140
The first eight bits, which is where
we get this FF and then the zero.

602
00:32:20.140 --> 00:32:22.330
So this last zero could actually
be something different.

603
00:32:22.330 --> 00:32:26.706
I could have FF01 or FF02, FF09, FF0B,

604
00:32:26.706 --> 00:32:30.140
all sorts of different values there.

605
00:32:30.140 --> 00:32:34.210
So FF00::/8.

606
00:32:34.210 --> 00:32:37.715
Any time you see an address that
starts with FF0, that's a multicast.

607
00:32:38.765 --> 00:32:42.865
So, for example,
let's say that you had DHCP.

608
00:32:42.865 --> 00:32:45.325
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

609
00:32:45.325 --> 00:32:47.495
You wanted to get an IP
address from the network.

610
00:32:47.495 --> 00:32:49.365
You wanted somebody to assign it to you.

611
00:32:49.365 --> 00:32:50.740
Well in the past you'd do a broadcast.

612
00:32:50.740 --> 00:32:53.155
You'd send a big message out
on the network saying hey,

613
00:32:53.155 --> 00:32:56.350
anybody out there can somebody
please give me an address?

614
00:32:56.350 --> 00:32:57.860
Well, in IPv6 you don't do that.

615
00:32:57.860 --> 00:33:02.660
You say all right,
DHCPv6 uses this multicast address.

616
00:33:02.660 --> 00:33:04.110
I'll talk to that address.

617
00:33:04.110 --> 00:33:06.640
And only the people listening
on that address will hear it.

618
00:33:06.640 --> 00:33:08.360
And those should be your DHCP servers.

619
00:33:08.360 --> 00:33:11.190
So they get the communication and
not everybody else.

620
00:33:11.190 --> 00:33:13.030
It's far more efficient.

621
00:33:13.030 --> 00:33:17.220
So multicast gets used a lot
because broadcast is gone.

622
00:33:17.220 --> 00:33:18.850
There's no broadcast in IPv6.

623
00:33:21.440 --> 00:33:24.550
Alright now, I mention that one because

624
00:33:24.550 --> 00:33:29.375
there is another neat little range that's
out there what's called a link-local.

625
00:33:30.400 --> 00:33:35.050
And the link-local range is FE8.

626
00:33:35.050 --> 00:33:39.130
And I'm gonna stick a zero
on the end of this one, too.

627
00:33:39.130 --> 00:33:42.490
But FE80 is the most
common one that we see.

628
00:33:42.490 --> 00:33:44.520
Whoop, too many slashes.

629
00:33:44.520 --> 00:33:46.910
But it could be, you know, FE81, FE82.

630
00:33:46.910 --> 00:33:49.870
It actually goes higher than that,
so you could add FE9.

631
00:33:49.870 --> 00:33:52.720
But FE8 is what we normally see.

632
00:33:52.720 --> 00:33:57.840
Anytime you see an address that
starts with FE8, that is a local only

633
00:33:57.840 --> 00:34:01.520
address that is non-routable.

634
00:34:01.520 --> 00:34:06.610
This one up here, this FC0, these guys up
here are local addresses, they're private.

635
00:34:06.610 --> 00:34:09.140
But they're routable,
a router will send them along.

636
00:34:09.140 --> 00:34:12.870
But FE8, that guy,
that's not routable, all right.

637
00:34:12.870 --> 00:34:15.040
When your system boots up for
the first time and

638
00:34:15.040 --> 00:34:18.140
connects to the network,
if it needs to get an IP address and

639
00:34:18.140 --> 00:34:21.790
it's gotta use a multicast to do it,
if it's gotta talk to one of these,

640
00:34:21.790 --> 00:34:24.770
how can it talk on the network if
it doesn't have an address itself?

641
00:34:24.770 --> 00:34:25.800
It can't.

642
00:34:25.800 --> 00:34:28.540
So it needs some kind of address.

643
00:34:28.540 --> 00:34:32.700
So, regardless of whether you set
an IP address on your interfaces,

644
00:34:32.700 --> 00:34:39.512
if you have IPv6 support, your system will
at a minimum have an FE8 address on it.

645
00:34:39.512 --> 00:34:44.080
If you're running Windows right now
Windows, ever since Windows Vista,

646
00:34:44.080 --> 00:34:46.250
IPv6 has been on by default, and

647
00:34:46.250 --> 00:34:50.270
you will likely have an an FE8 address
attached to your system right now.

648
00:34:50.270 --> 00:34:52.370
MacOS, same way.

649
00:34:52.370 --> 00:34:54.860
Even if you haven't turned on IPv6,
if you're not using it,

650
00:34:54.860 --> 00:34:58.280
it's on by default, and
you'll likely have that address.

651
00:34:58.280 --> 00:35:00.500
My laptop should be like that,
here, let's find out.

652
00:35:00.500 --> 00:35:06.090
So, I'm not using IPv6 on my system,
but If I do a quick IF config and

653
00:35:06.090 --> 00:35:09.710
start to look at some of the addresses
attached to mine, right here.

654
00:35:09.710 --> 00:35:13.421
So here's my network adapter and
10.1.230.243,

655
00:35:13.421 --> 00:35:17.623
that's my IPv4 address,
that's what I'm actually using right now.

656
00:35:17.623 --> 00:35:26.786
But look right above it
FE80::6A5B:35FF:FE blah blah blah, right?

657
00:35:26.786 --> 00:35:28.100
So you're seeing all of that right there.

658
00:35:28.100 --> 00:35:31.050
That is my address.

659
00:35:31.050 --> 00:35:32.650
It's a link-local address.

660
00:35:32.650 --> 00:35:36.100
It was generated by my system for
use just so

661
00:35:36.100 --> 00:35:39.550
it could find other people
out there on the network.

662
00:35:39.550 --> 00:35:43.140
So that is the one that my laptop has.

663
00:35:43.140 --> 00:35:43.760
All right.

664
00:35:43.760 --> 00:35:46.110
I didn't set that,
I didn't tell it to use it.

665
00:35:46.110 --> 00:35:48.340
It came up with it on its own, all right.

666
00:35:48.340 --> 00:35:50.820
It's using that, and it goes and
starts to communicate.

667
00:35:50.820 --> 00:35:53.560
Now, there's always a possibility
you can get a duplicate

668
00:35:53.560 --> 00:35:55.810
when you have an automatically
generated address like this.

669
00:35:55.810 --> 00:35:57.360
So it does do duplicate detection,

670
00:35:57.360 --> 00:36:00.000
it looks out on the network to
see if anybody else has it.

671
00:36:00.000 --> 00:36:02.450
And if they don't,
then E uses it, and off it goes.

672
00:36:02.450 --> 00:36:04.910
If somebody does,
it just picks another one, right?

673
00:36:04.910 --> 00:36:07.542
But that's an address that we can use for
our initial communications.

674
00:36:07.542 --> 00:36:10.670
It's non routeable though, so
we can just it for local stuff,

675
00:36:10.670 --> 00:36:13.370
people that are right there on
the same network as us, and

676
00:36:13.370 --> 00:36:16.370
if we wanna get any further,
we'll need to get a better address.

677
00:36:18.530 --> 00:36:22.590
All right, other addresses that we might
see, there's one special one, I do want

678
00:36:22.590 --> 00:36:26.920
to point this one out, it's kind of silly,
but It's called the documentation range.

679
00:36:28.070 --> 00:36:34.919
And it is 2001: DB8::/32.

680
00:36:34.919 --> 00:36:36.281
That one right there, all right?

681
00:36:36.281 --> 00:36:38.830
This one is used in textbooks.

682
00:36:38.830 --> 00:36:42.680
They actually set this aside, they say
we wanna set this range aside because

683
00:36:42.680 --> 00:36:47.500
a lot of people use IP examples in books,
and they pick an IP that's

684
00:36:47.500 --> 00:36:50.860
really used out there on the internet,
and that can be a problem because

685
00:36:50.860 --> 00:36:54.620
by the time that book publishes, that IP
might not be in use anymore or whatever.

686
00:36:54.620 --> 00:36:57.590
So we need something we
can use in the books, and

687
00:36:57.590 --> 00:37:00.000
that's what this one is designed for.

688
00:37:00.000 --> 00:37:04.060
In the chatroom Favian just
mentioned is FE80 like APIPA, right?

689
00:37:04.060 --> 00:37:06.540
The Automatic Private IP Addressing.

690
00:37:06.540 --> 00:37:09.330
And yeah, that's actually a great example.

691
00:37:09.330 --> 00:37:14.240
In IPv4, we have APIPA which
generates those 169.254 addresses.

692
00:37:14.240 --> 00:37:16.410
Let me see, I've got that right here.

693
00:37:16.410 --> 00:37:20.714
So if you can't find a server to
give you an IP, you make one up,

694
00:37:20.714 --> 00:37:24.552
169.254 dot something dot something,
right?

695
00:37:24.552 --> 00:37:28.503
And that's effectively
what your IPv6 systems do,

696
00:37:28.503 --> 00:37:32.205
is they go in and they generate,
wait where was I?

697
00:37:32.205 --> 00:37:33.186
I got lost!

698
00:37:33.186 --> 00:37:34.990
Here we go.
[LAUGH] They go in and

699
00:37:34.990 --> 00:37:38.695
they generate a FE80 and
then a bunch of zeroes and

700
00:37:38.695 --> 00:37:44.490
then the last 64 bits they dynamically
generate so it's very similar.

701
00:37:44.490 --> 00:37:49.310
The only difference is with APIPA,
when a DHP server comes back up and

702
00:37:49.310 --> 00:37:52.780
you get a real address,
your APIPA address goes away.

703
00:37:52.780 --> 00:37:57.390
So you've only got an APIPA address
when there's a problem, all right?

704
00:37:57.390 --> 00:38:02.170
But an FE80 address,
that link-local, you always have it.

705
00:38:02.170 --> 00:38:04.180
Even when you've got a good address,

706
00:38:04.180 --> 00:38:09.890
with IPv6 it is very common to have more
than one address on the same interface.

707
00:38:09.890 --> 00:38:13.170
So often times you'll have
your public address and

708
00:38:13.170 --> 00:38:16.780
your FE8 link-local address
right there side by side.

709
00:38:16.780 --> 00:38:17.350
You can do that.

710
00:38:17.350 --> 00:38:20.180
You can have many many addresses
attached to the interface.

711
00:38:20.180 --> 00:38:23.470
You can actually do that under IPv4 too
but there's not much reason for it.

712
00:38:23.470 --> 00:38:24.890
But in IPv6 there is.

713
00:38:24.890 --> 00:38:26.770
So you may see that.

714
00:38:26.770 --> 00:38:27.710
Yeah, great question thank you.

715
00:38:29.910 --> 00:38:33.440
All right so the documentation one,
that's just for textbooks and

716
00:38:33.440 --> 00:38:36.830
technically people like me, where I'm
using examples here on the screen,

717
00:38:36.830 --> 00:38:41.490
that's what I should be using 2001:DB8
it's not in use out in the internet but

718
00:38:41.490 --> 00:38:46.410
it is what would normally be in
the publicly registered range.

719
00:38:46.410 --> 00:38:51.420
If you go and get a registered
IPv6 network from IANA, right

720
00:38:51.420 --> 00:38:56.950
now their issuing in the 2001's and 2002's
that's where their issuing from right now.

721
00:38:56.950 --> 00:38:59.720
And as they fill up they'll go to 2003 and
so on.

722
00:38:59.720 --> 00:39:03.070
So most of your public addresses
are starting with 200.

723
00:39:03.070 --> 00:39:03.980
You don't have to, right?

724
00:39:03.980 --> 00:39:06.180
You've got a wide range of
addresses that are out there.

725
00:39:06.180 --> 00:39:07.910
But that's kind of where
they pick to start.

726
00:39:09.270 --> 00:39:11.375
I'm not actually sure
of the logic of that,

727
00:39:11.375 --> 00:39:14.220
like why they decided to start there,
but that is where they started.

728
00:39:16.042 --> 00:39:20.400
All right, so those are some special
ranges that we'll see inside of IPv6.

729
00:39:22.120 --> 00:39:26.630
Now, with IPv6, your address space is big.

730
00:39:26.630 --> 00:39:27.890
All right?

731
00:39:27.890 --> 00:39:33.190
And, as a result, a lot of the things we
do under IPv4 won't be necessary anymore.

732
00:39:33.190 --> 00:39:35.020
In IPv4, a lot of times,

733
00:39:35.020 --> 00:39:39.790
we use private IPs inside of our network,
just because we don't have enough publics.

734
00:39:39.790 --> 00:39:43.560
So we use private, and
then we use a router, a device like that

735
00:39:43.560 --> 00:39:46.600
to hide all of our internal IPs
when they go out to the Internet.

736
00:39:46.600 --> 00:39:50.708
But with IPv6 the address space is so
big, you don't need to hide anymore.

737
00:39:50.708 --> 00:39:54.444
You can give everybody a real public IP
and they can go right out to the internet

738
00:39:54.444 --> 00:39:57.490
without having to do network
address translation.

739
00:39:57.490 --> 00:40:00.808
And I know if any of you guys are security
professionals out there, you're like oh,

740
00:40:00.808 --> 00:40:01.709
why would you do that?

741
00:40:01.709 --> 00:40:04.110
Why would you give a public
IP to every system?

742
00:40:04.110 --> 00:40:07.940
Well, NAT, Network Address Translation,
what hides those IPs,

743
00:40:07.940 --> 00:40:10.580
is really a sham for security.

744
00:40:10.580 --> 00:40:12.310
It's security through obscurity.

745
00:40:12.310 --> 00:40:14.400
It just hides things,
it doesn't actually protect them.

746
00:40:14.400 --> 00:40:18.410
And it's not that difficult to pull
an attack through a net router.

747
00:40:18.410 --> 00:40:21.580
So it was really a false sense
of security in the first place.

748
00:40:21.580 --> 00:40:22.940
So don't think of it that way.

749
00:40:22.940 --> 00:40:26.680
You'll still have things like firewalls,
and VPN tunnels and other devices like

750
00:40:26.680 --> 00:40:31.830
that to secure your network, but when each
machine has their own public IP, a lot of

751
00:40:31.830 --> 00:40:37.830
the stuff like port forwarding, and all of
that UPnP automatic network configuration.

752
00:40:37.830 --> 00:40:41.360
All that crazy junk that you might have
had to deal with at home before goes away.

753
00:40:41.360 --> 00:40:44.960
We don't need that anymore, and
the network works a lot more reliably.

754
00:40:44.960 --> 00:40:47.350
So definitely some big
benefits to having that.

755
00:40:49.090 --> 00:40:54.860
All right, now that FE80 address,
I mentioned that it makes it up.

756
00:40:54.860 --> 00:40:58.119
Well, it's actually not just
making it up from thin air.

757
00:40:58.119 --> 00:41:02.094
With IPv6, there's

758
00:41:02.094 --> 00:41:07.327
a process called EUI-64.

759
00:41:07.327 --> 00:41:10.300
And EUI-64, it's a little standard.

760
00:41:10.300 --> 00:41:13.430
It actually stands for, oh,
shoot, I always forget this, and

761
00:41:13.430 --> 00:41:14.240
I thought I wrote it down.

762
00:41:14.240 --> 00:41:14.750
But you know what?

763
00:41:14.750 --> 00:41:16.110
I didn't.

764
00:41:16.110 --> 00:41:20.692
But it's an unique IP generation,
is what it stands for, and

765
00:41:20.692 --> 00:41:25.190
what it does is it helps you
to get that unique address.

766
00:41:25.190 --> 00:41:29.150
The problem is, how can one system
just create a unique address?

767
00:41:29.150 --> 00:41:34.810
Well, it knows that a link local,
for example, has to start with FE8.

768
00:41:34.810 --> 00:41:39.120
And so when EUI-64 goes to build
the address, it assumes that it's gonna be

769
00:41:39.120 --> 00:41:41.660
a link-local,
that's where we start, all right.

770
00:41:41.660 --> 00:41:45.733
And with a link-local, because it's
non-routable, part of the address

771
00:41:45.733 --> 00:41:50.202
represents the network, but it doesn't
really matter cuz it's non-routable.

772
00:41:50.202 --> 00:41:53.010
So it always uses the same one, FE80.

773
00:41:53.010 --> 00:41:58.041
And if I write that all the way out,
it would be

774
00:41:58.041 --> 00:42:04.411
FE80:0000:0000:0000, all right?

775
00:42:04.411 --> 00:42:07.786
That's the first half of the address.

776
00:42:07.786 --> 00:42:09.162
But then there's more, right?

777
00:42:09.162 --> 00:42:12.630
The rest of it comes afterwards.

778
00:42:12.630 --> 00:42:17.025
And this is the part that's gonna be
set for that individual client and

779
00:42:17.025 --> 00:42:18.452
it needs to be unique.

780
00:42:18.452 --> 00:42:23.014
So the first 64 bits of my address,
it's 128 bits,

781
00:42:23.014 --> 00:42:26.161
the first half would be FE80000.

782
00:42:26.161 --> 00:42:29.411
So in APIPA, we had 169.254.

783
00:42:29.411 --> 00:42:32.618
Here we have FE80000.

784
00:42:32.618 --> 00:42:33.287
All right.

785
00:42:33.287 --> 00:42:36.084
And then this second half of the address,
we need to generate.

786
00:42:36.084 --> 00:42:40.630
And what EUI-64 says is, boy,

787
00:42:40.630 --> 00:42:46.160
wouldn't it be nice if we had
some kind of a hexadecimal number

788
00:42:46.160 --> 00:42:49.810
that uniquely identified this machine
where we didn't have duplicates?

789
00:42:49.810 --> 00:42:51.560
Wouldn't it be nice if that existed?

790
00:42:51.560 --> 00:42:53.494
Well unfortunately we don't have that.

791
00:42:53.494 --> 00:42:56.745
But we do have a 48-bit number.

792
00:42:56.745 --> 00:42:59.250
You might have noticed looking
at the exam objectives.

793
00:42:59.250 --> 00:43:00.840
Let me pull the exam objectives up.

794
00:43:00.840 --> 00:43:03.320
There's an interesting
little note in here.

795
00:43:03.320 --> 00:43:06.540
So we're talking about explaining the
purpose and properties of IP addressing.

796
00:43:07.550 --> 00:43:11.630
But in the objectives,
they call out a MAC address.

797
00:43:11.630 --> 00:43:13.520
Why would they mention a MAC address here?

798
00:43:13.520 --> 00:43:15.541
If you remember the OSI model,

799
00:43:15.541 --> 00:43:18.663
MAC addresses are at layer
two of the OSS model.

800
00:43:18.663 --> 00:43:20.952
And IP addresses are at
layer three of the OSS.

801
00:43:20.952 --> 00:43:22.310
These are different layers.

802
00:43:22.310 --> 00:43:22.900
Right?

803
00:43:22.900 --> 00:43:25.360
MACs don't influence IPs.

804
00:43:25.360 --> 00:43:27.020
And IPs don't influence MACs.

805
00:43:27.020 --> 00:43:28.619
So why is that here?

806
00:43:28.619 --> 00:43:31.536
Well the reason is UI64.

807
00:43:31.536 --> 00:43:36.960
A MAC address is a hardware address
that's burned into your network adapter.

808
00:43:38.090 --> 00:43:41.460
MAC stands for media access control.

809
00:43:41.460 --> 00:43:42.930
It's not Mac like Macintosh.

810
00:43:42.930 --> 00:43:47.240
Right, it's media access control, and
it identifies your network adapter.

811
00:43:47.240 --> 00:43:50.640
If you have a wireless adapter,
it's got a MAC burned into it.

812
00:43:50.640 --> 00:43:53.320
If you've got a physical adapter,
it's got a MAC burned into it.

813
00:43:53.320 --> 00:43:56.110
If you've got a fiber
optic network adapter

814
00:43:56.110 --> 00:43:57.490
it has a MAC address burned into it.

815
00:43:57.490 --> 00:43:59.100
They've all got MAC addresses.

816
00:43:59.100 --> 00:44:03.430
If they talk on an ethernet network,
they will have a MAC address, all right.

817
00:44:03.430 --> 00:44:10.202
And that MAC address is 48 bits and
it's hexadecimal.

818
00:44:10.202 --> 00:44:13.452
It's almost perfect for
what we need in IPv6.

819
00:44:13.452 --> 00:44:18.412
It's 48 bits, hexadecimal and
uniquely identifies your adapter.

820
00:44:18.412 --> 00:44:19.702
There's not going to be a duplicate.

821
00:44:19.702 --> 00:44:25.020
There's not going to be a duplicate on
your network, and so EUI 64 uses that.

822
00:44:25.020 --> 00:44:25.590
All right.

823
00:44:25.590 --> 00:44:28.500
But before I go too far into it,
let's talk a little bit more about MAC

824
00:44:28.500 --> 00:44:31.360
addresses, because some of you might
not have been exposed to that before.

825
00:44:31.360 --> 00:44:34.410
A MAC address is going to look
something like this, right.

826
00:44:34.410 --> 00:44:38.200
So MAC, let me move this up on my screen.

827
00:44:38.200 --> 00:44:42.150
MAC, that's media access control,

828
00:44:43.470 --> 00:44:47.630
it's a 48 bit hexadecimal number.

829
00:44:48.780 --> 00:44:50.950
Or hexadecimal, cuz it's not.

830
00:44:50.950 --> 00:44:53.630
Hexidecimal you can have letters,
so it's not necessarily a number.

831
00:44:53.630 --> 00:44:56.160
And it's assigned by
the hardware manufacturers.

832
00:44:59.370 --> 00:45:00.410
All right?

833
00:45:00.410 --> 00:45:03.430
But, it's not just made up out
of the blue by them either.

834
00:45:03.430 --> 00:45:05.900
There's an organization called the IEEE.

835
00:45:05.900 --> 00:45:07.900
They're an engineering organization.

836
00:45:07.900 --> 00:45:11.060
And they put together a lot of
the standards that we use in computing.

837
00:45:11.060 --> 00:45:14.460
In the IEEE you're the one
who defined MAC addresses.

838
00:45:14.460 --> 00:45:16.768
An example of a MAC address would
be something like this, and

839
00:45:16.768 --> 00:45:18.411
there's a few different ways to write it.

840
00:45:18.411 --> 00:45:22.911
So it might be written as,
let me just make one up.

841
00:45:22.911 --> 00:45:27.461
You know what, here, let me just use
the own from my own laptop here so

842
00:45:27.461 --> 00:45:29.827
That is my MAC address right there.

843
00:45:38.160 --> 00:45:39.200
There.

844
00:45:39.200 --> 00:45:40.911
All right.
This is one way to right it.

845
00:45:40.911 --> 00:45:43.020
These are hexadecimal letters.

846
00:45:43.020 --> 00:45:46.460
Notice how we've got a B and I've got a C,
right, those letters mixed in there.

847
00:45:46.460 --> 00:45:50.540
And we've got two digits and a colon,
two digits and a colon and so on.

848
00:45:50.540 --> 00:45:52.340
That's one way to write it.

849
00:45:52.340 --> 00:45:57.090
Another way to write it is,
instead of colons, to use dashes.

850
00:45:57.090 --> 00:46:00.120
You'll see people do this pretty commonly.

851
00:46:00.120 --> 00:46:00.910
All right.

852
00:46:00.910 --> 00:46:06.065
And there is a third way to write it which
you'll see some vendors use, especially

853
00:46:06.065 --> 00:46:10.560
Cisco, where they do it in groups of
four separated with some periods.

854
00:46:11.830 --> 00:46:12.880
Like that.

855
00:46:12.880 --> 00:46:13.710
Okay.

856
00:46:13.710 --> 00:46:15.450
But at the end of the day
it doesn't matter.

857
00:46:15.450 --> 00:46:16.786
They all mean the same thing.

858
00:46:16.786 --> 00:46:22.244
They're all a 48 bit, hexadecimal system
that identifies my network adapter.

859
00:46:22.244 --> 00:46:23.118
All right?

860
00:46:23.118 --> 00:46:27.702
Now on the 48 bits, the first 24 bits.

861
00:46:27.702 --> 00:46:34.200
So the first 24 bits,
that identifies The vendor.

862
00:46:34.200 --> 00:46:36.210
Who made the device, all right?

863
00:46:36.210 --> 00:46:37.160
Was it Intel?

864
00:46:37.160 --> 00:46:37.960
Was it Broadcom?

865
00:46:37.960 --> 00:46:40.560
Was it HP or Dell or Apple, or whoever?

866
00:46:40.560 --> 00:46:44.020
Who was it that made that
network interface, all right?

867
00:46:44.020 --> 00:46:45.940
That one is called a OUI.

868
00:46:48.910 --> 00:46:53.230
And that is the organizationally
unique identifier.

869
00:46:53.230 --> 00:46:54.860
That's a mouthful.

870
00:46:54.860 --> 00:46:58.842
Organizationally unique identifier.

871
00:46:58.842 --> 00:47:02.230
All right so, it's identifying
the organization and what'll happen is if

872
00:47:02.230 --> 00:47:04.830
you're a company, let's say you decide
today hey I'm gonna open up a company that

873
00:47:04.830 --> 00:47:08.920
makes network cards or makes some device
that has a network jack on it like Roku.

874
00:47:08.920 --> 00:47:11.160
Roku decides hey they're
gonna make these boxes and

875
00:47:11.160 --> 00:47:12.820
they've got network jacks on them.

876
00:47:12.820 --> 00:47:14.570
They're going to need MAC addresses.

877
00:47:14.570 --> 00:47:19.500
So, they call up the IEEE and they say,
hey we're a new business we're going to be

878
00:47:19.500 --> 00:47:23.610
putting in network jacks into our systems
we're going to make them ourselves we're

879
00:47:23.610 --> 00:47:26.770
not going to buy them from intel or
whatever, we're making them ourselves.

880
00:47:26.770 --> 00:47:30.957
The IEEE will say okay,
let me give you an OUI and

881
00:47:30.957 --> 00:47:34.537
they'll give them the first 24 bits.

882
00:47:34.537 --> 00:47:39.526
All right, and
that will leave them with 24 more bits

883
00:47:39.526 --> 00:47:44.202
right there to be able to
assign to their hardware.

884
00:47:44.202 --> 00:47:50.251
24 bits is enough to generate 16.7
million individual unique MAC addresses.

885
00:47:50.251 --> 00:47:54.684
So as long as they manufacture
less than 16.7 million devices,

886
00:47:54.684 --> 00:47:57.418
they'll fit right there in that one OUI.

887
00:47:57.418 --> 00:48:00.928
But, if they do more, right,
if they're really successful, and

888
00:48:00.928 --> 00:48:03.920
they sell more than that,
then they'll need more OUIs.

889
00:48:03.920 --> 00:48:06.546
And they'll go back to the IEEE and
they'll say, hey guys, sorry,

890
00:48:06.546 --> 00:48:08.696
we kind of used that whole one,
can we have another one?

891
00:48:08.696 --> 00:48:09.714
And they'll get another one.

892
00:48:09.714 --> 00:48:16.880
And so a company may have more than one
OUI but, they'll never issue duplicates.

893
00:48:16.880 --> 00:48:18.630
They won't reuse the addresses.

894
00:48:18.630 --> 00:48:22.860
So as they just fill up one OUI, they
just go to the next one and continue on.

895
00:48:22.860 --> 00:48:27.890
Companies like Apple, HP,
Dell they have a multitude of OUIs.

896
00:48:27.890 --> 00:48:31.300
They may have five, six, ten OUIs.

897
00:48:31.300 --> 00:48:34.801
Smaller companies though,
you take somebody like,

898
00:48:34.801 --> 00:48:38.470
I don't know who manufactures,
well, Roku, right?

899
00:48:38.470 --> 00:48:41.449
I don't know that Roku has
sold 16.7 million Rokus.

900
00:48:41.449 --> 00:48:46.170
So they may still be on their original OUI
or they may not have their own at all.

901
00:48:46.170 --> 00:48:49.460
If they're buying their network
adapters from Intel or Broadcom,

902
00:48:49.460 --> 00:48:54.130
then that's the company that's actually
gonna be assigning the address to it, so

903
00:48:54.130 --> 00:48:56.180
it may not even be Roku identified at all.

904
00:48:57.960 --> 00:49:01.250
If you're ever curious and you want to
look it up though, you can take the first

905
00:49:01.250 --> 00:49:06.570
half of that address and you can look
it up against the IEEE's website.

906
00:49:06.570 --> 00:49:11.440
They do expect it to be either with
hyphens or with nothing at all,

907
00:49:11.440 --> 00:49:13.180
just the six digits all in a row.

908
00:49:13.180 --> 00:49:17.630
But you just take those first six
characters and you can copy that and

909
00:49:17.630 --> 00:49:19.470
jump over to the IEEE's webpage.

910
00:49:19.470 --> 00:49:20.950
So I've got it pulled up back here.

911
00:49:20.950 --> 00:49:23.660
So here's
the IEEE's Standards Association, and

912
00:49:23.660 --> 00:49:27.390
they have a MAC address
look up tool on their site.

913
00:49:27.390 --> 00:49:31.040
And I'll post the URL to
this with the show notes.

914
00:49:31.040 --> 00:49:34.650
But you can come down here and just punch
in that first part of the MAC address.

915
00:49:34.650 --> 00:49:38.742
So there's my first part of the MAC
address, and I'll hit Search.

916
00:49:38.742 --> 00:49:45.486
And it's gonna look it up and tell me,
that OUI 685B35 is Apple right?

917
00:49:45.486 --> 00:49:48.808
I'm on a MacBook here, so
that's an Apple address and

918
00:49:48.808 --> 00:49:52.450
here's their mailing address so
you can find them.

919
00:49:52.450 --> 00:49:56.390
So, they keep that in a database,
they manage it, they issue it, and

920
00:49:56.390 --> 00:49:58.690
you can actually download the whole
database, they've got right here.

921
00:49:58.690 --> 00:50:00.813
You can download a copy of it.

922
00:50:00.813 --> 00:50:02.790
They update it daily,
and you can pull it up.

923
00:50:02.790 --> 00:50:04.130
I forget, I think it's just text.

924
00:50:04.130 --> 00:50:05.170
Yeah, here it is.

925
00:50:05.170 --> 00:50:05.860
And when you pull it up,

926
00:50:05.860 --> 00:50:09.710
you'll see the early ones are really
old companies like Xerox.

927
00:50:09.710 --> 00:50:14.160
Xerox was a pioneer in the world of
Ethernet, and so that's why they've got so

928
00:50:14.160 --> 00:50:17.960
much of the beginning ones, but
see how Xerox has several of these.

929
00:50:17.960 --> 00:50:19.050
And then you've got other companies,

930
00:50:19.050 --> 00:50:23.940
there was Fujitsu, Oracle,
Prodigy, good old Prodigy.

931
00:50:23.940 --> 00:50:27.500
But you'll see a bunch of companies
ranging from small ones to big ones, and

932
00:50:27.500 --> 00:50:31.430
it just depends on how much
equipment they have generated.

933
00:50:31.430 --> 00:50:35.089
There's more Apple right there, and
we'll probably find Apple several times

934
00:50:35.089 --> 00:50:37.668
throughout it,
every time they fill up an OUI, right.

935
00:50:37.668 --> 00:50:43.585
So we could search for somebody like Roku,
and that's like a city there.

936
00:50:43.585 --> 00:50:44.535
There we go, Roku.

937
00:50:44.535 --> 00:50:48.491
So Roku actually has at least one OUI,
000d4b.

938
00:50:48.491 --> 00:50:52.730
So there's that one, and if we keep
searching, we might find more, or

939
00:50:52.730 --> 00:50:53.645
we might not.

940
00:50:53.645 --> 00:50:54.735
There's another one, right?

941
00:50:54.735 --> 00:50:57.505
So they have sold more
than 16.7 million devices,

942
00:50:57.505 --> 00:51:00.900
because we can see they've
pulled another OUI.

943
00:51:00.900 --> 00:51:03.320
Pretty neat stuff you know,
it's all right there.

944
00:51:03.320 --> 00:51:09.063
So I've kind of diverged from my original
topic though which is how we use this for

945
00:51:09.063 --> 00:51:09.998
EUI-64.

946
00:51:09.998 --> 00:51:13.613
EUI-64 says hey I need
to generate a 64 bit,

947
00:51:13.613 --> 00:51:18.480
hexadecimal number that's
unique to this machine.

948
00:51:18.480 --> 00:51:20.460
A MAC address would be perfect right?

949
00:51:20.460 --> 00:51:22.120
It's only 48 bits.

950
00:51:22.120 --> 00:51:25.530
But if we just pad it a little bit, we
stick some extra values in there, it can

951
00:51:25.530 --> 00:51:29.340
be 64 bit and it's already unique so
we don't have to worry about duplicates.

952
00:51:29.340 --> 00:51:31.200
And that's exactly what it does.

953
00:51:31.200 --> 00:51:36.710
What it does is it takes that MAC address,
so this is my MAC address, all right, and

954
00:51:36.710 --> 00:51:42.440
EUI-64 will take that and
stick some more stuff in there.

955
00:51:42.440 --> 00:51:45.298
And where did I write EUI-64?

956
00:51:45.298 --> 00:51:46.130
I guess I didn't.

957
00:51:46.130 --> 00:51:50.202
So what EUI-64 will do is take
that MAC address like mine.

958
00:51:53.263 --> 00:51:57.855
So here's my original media
access control address, and

959
00:51:57.855 --> 00:52:04.690
it will then pad it, so my padded MAC,
it's gonna go straight to the middle.

960
00:52:04.690 --> 00:52:08.190
And in the middle of it,
in between the two paths, right?

961
00:52:08.190 --> 00:52:10.512
So you got 24 bits on the left,
24 bits on the right.

962
00:52:10.512 --> 00:52:16.743
It's gonna add FF:FE:.

963
00:52:16.743 --> 00:52:20.590
Those two extra values there, FF, FE.

964
00:52:20.590 --> 00:52:25.845
That's how you can spot an EUI-64 address,
it will take that and

965
00:52:25.845 --> 00:52:31.697
there's 64 bits, and
now it can build my EUI-64 address.

966
00:52:34.925 --> 00:52:38.369
And it will look just like this.

967
00:52:38.369 --> 00:52:40.938
Just gonna throw that in there,
that's the first half and

968
00:52:40.938 --> 00:52:43.885
then we'll take this in here and
throw it in the second half.

969
00:52:43.885 --> 00:52:45.665
I got a lot more colons than I need, so

970
00:52:45.665 --> 00:52:50.395
I gotta take those out to
conform to IPv6's arrangement.

971
00:52:50.395 --> 00:52:52.630
Whoops, that was not one of them.

972
00:52:52.630 --> 00:52:57.610
There, and you'll see there's that
link local address written out, and

973
00:52:57.610 --> 00:53:03.100
they got a full 128 bits,
that basically guaranteed to be unique.

974
00:53:03.100 --> 00:53:06.430
There's no other network adapter on my
physical network that should have that

975
00:53:06.430 --> 00:53:08.510
same MAC address, it's now unique.

976
00:53:08.510 --> 00:53:11.640
So it's a neat way to generate that
address without creating a duplicate, and

977
00:53:11.640 --> 00:53:12.600
if a duplicate is detected,

978
00:53:12.600 --> 00:53:15.790
it will just randomly generate one,
to pick on that isn't in use.

979
00:53:15.790 --> 00:53:20.620
But it's doing that and you might have
noticed that when you look at my machine,

980
00:53:20.620 --> 00:53:25.130
so here's my machine and
my FEA address, there's my link local.

981
00:53:25.130 --> 00:53:30.110
Notice right in the middle of that FFFE,
I can spot it right there.

982
00:53:30.110 --> 00:53:34.160
That's my machine generating
one of these EUI-64 link

983
00:53:34.160 --> 00:53:36.740
local addresses to be able to talk.

984
00:53:36.740 --> 00:53:39.500
IPV6 is very automated.

985
00:53:39.500 --> 00:53:43.340
It can generate a lot of connectivity
without us having to do anything.

986
00:53:43.340 --> 00:53:44.880
So it is really powerful.

987
00:53:44.880 --> 00:53:46.500
It's an exciting protocol.

988
00:53:46.500 --> 00:53:49.090
A lot of us are really looking
forward to the day when we

989
00:53:49.090 --> 00:53:52.030
finally get to roll this out and
put it in action.

990
00:53:54.280 --> 00:53:58.678
All right so
that's probably enough on IPv6.

991
00:53:58.678 --> 00:54:03.038
I could go on a lot more but
this is Network+.

992
00:54:03.038 --> 00:54:04.670
This is your first exposure to IPv6 and

993
00:54:04.670 --> 00:54:07.880
I don't want to blow your mind
any more than we already have.

994
00:54:07.880 --> 00:54:11.780
If you want to learn more about IPv6,
I encourage you to jump over to

995
00:54:11.780 --> 00:54:16.190
one of our CCNA shows like
the Cisco CCNT and CCNA show.

996
00:54:16.190 --> 00:54:20.170
There, not only do we talk about IPv6,
but we show how to implement it.

997

We configure it on some Cisco routers and
get it going there.

998
00:54:23.200 --> 00:54:26.512
You'll also see it in some of
the Windows Server shows that we do,

999
00:54:26.512 --> 00:54:27.911
Windows Server 2012.

1000
00:54:27.911 --> 00:54:32.250
We set up some of the services there and
show how to do DNS lookups and all that.

1001
00:54:32.250 --> 00:54:33.970
So there's a lot more to it.

1002
00:54:33.970 --> 00:54:36.750
But this is enough for
an introduction and definitely covers

1003
00:54:36.750 --> 00:54:39.670
all the things that you're gonna
see on the exam based around IPv6.

1004
00:54:41.150 --> 00:54:44.610
All right, well, that is not
the end of IP addressing for us.

1005
00:54:44.610 --> 00:54:45.770
We still have a little more to go.

1006
00:54:45.770 --> 00:54:48.570
We haven't even talked about subnets yet.

1007
00:54:48.570 --> 00:54:52.880
But for IPv6 that's a wrap so this is
a pretty good stopping point for us.

1008
00:54:52.880 --> 00:54:55.410
Now if you have any questions
I don't blame you, right.

1009
00:54:55.410 --> 00:54:58.510
It's definitely a big
amount to swallow there.

1010
00:54:58.510 --> 00:55:01.530
So, if you have questions,
feel free to ask.

Live during the show you

At the top of every page

1021

episodes.description: In this episode Don begins the multipart series on IPv4 subnetting. He begins with a detailed discussion on what a subnet is, what it does and what we use it for. He continues with explaining the process of decimal to binary conversion and how to determine whether an IP address is part of the same network as another address.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting

episodes.description: In this episode Don continues with a discussion on IPv4 subnetting with leveraging the use of subnets to create smaller or larger network to optimize network performance. He uses examples of splitting and combining networks to ensure enough IP address are available for network devices.
episodes.title: IPv4 Subnetting Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie take a look into the working with switches and the purpose of switching.  They introduce the concept of switching as a centralized connectivity device that provides forwarding, flooding and filtering of data to all the devices that are plugged into a switch. They identify and describe the basic IEEE 802.1q VLAN tagging concept.  They also describe some of the issues in a redundant switch topology (working with multiple switches with multiple paths) and how Spanning Tree Protocol functions.
episodes.title: Switching

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie introduce the concept of working with routers and how routers function.  Routers help us to forward data between different IP networks but can only do so if they have routes they can see.  Wes and Ronnie show internal hardware of a basic router and talk about how routers can build the routing tables they need to forward data to other networks.  They introduce the concepts of static and dynamic routing and describe how some of the routing protocols work.
episodes.title: Routers

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss the most common ports used in networking.  They provide the background of using ports between a source and destination computer.  The ports are important to keeping network traffic separated between source and destination.  Using Wireshark, they display the port information while making an http, ftp and telnet connection across a network.
episodes.title: Identifying Common TCP/UDP Ports

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Wes discuss some of the common networking protocols every Network+ professional should be familiar with. They give examples and scenarios of the use of these protocols.
episodes.title: Common Network Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode, Nate and Ronnie discuss the one most common protocols used in networking, DNS (Domain Name System).  DNS helps us to resolve names to IP addresses to make it easier for people to network. People can use names instead of IP addresses to connect to machines.  Nate and Ronnie talk about the structure of DNS, they describe the function of DNS server and the components that make DNS work.  They demonstrate the DNS process works and show the different records and how to manually create a record too.
episodes.title: DNS Concepts

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Ronnie take a look at the network troubleshooting methodology. They discuss the steps every Network+ professional should be familiar with then diagnosing network issues. They give examples of identifying the problem, establishing a plan and verifying full system functionality.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Methodology

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at virtual networking components and its role in powering cloud computing. They discuss components such as network as a service (NaaS) as well as virtual PBXs and onsite vs. offsite components.
episodes.title: Virtual Network Components

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike take a look at the technology encountered when configuring routers and switches such as address translation and traffic filtering.
episodes.title: Routers and Switches

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike discuss the planning and configuring of a wireless network such as WAP placement, antenna types and channel selection.
episodes.title: Configure a Wireless Network

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don examine the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). They take a look at the concept and theory of DHCP and then demonstrate implementing DHCP in a network environment.
episodes.title: DHCP

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don continue to explore the area of network troubleshooting. They work through a series of network issues and demonstrate how to diagnose and repair the issue using CompTIA's recommended troubleshooting methodology.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don explore the world of designing and implementing a small office or home office network. They take a look at the various components that make up a SOHO network as well as other considerations of that design.
episodes.title: Building a SOHO Network

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take look at various media types and connector types.
episodes.title: Network Media

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at the various wireless standards covered by IEEE 802.11. They explore the characteristics and behavior of each protocol and explain real world uses.
episodes.title: Network Media Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at wide area network (WAN) connections. They discuss technologies ranging from standard business connections like cable broadband and T1 lines all the way through ISP level connections like OC192s.
episodes.title: WAN Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Nate discuss different types of network topologies such as star, mesh, and networking models such as client-server. They also explain the different LAN technologies and properties of each.
episodes.title: Technologies and Topologies

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at cabling design and documentation. They discuss the common methods for cabling a building and then discus the various ways of documenting the physical and logical networks.
episodes.title: Wiring Distribution

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at various network appliances such as load balances and proxy servers. They also demonstrate network monitoring using SNMP and network sniffers.
episodes.title: Network Management

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don discuss troubleshooting network issues and the assorted network tools than can be used to isolate the problem.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don take a look at network optimization technologies. They discuss hardware and software solutions that can help a network be resilient and efficient.
episodes.title: Network Optimization

episodes.description: In this ITProTV special Ronnie and Don answer a question from the Q&A. They describe Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) in detail and then demonstrate several real-world examples of collecting and interpreting SNMP data for monitoring purposes.
episodes.title: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don discuss wireless security measures and methods of user authentication. They demonstrate device placement and signal strength planning as well as authenticating on remote resources.
episodes.title: Network Security

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don take a look at methods of securing network access. They discuss access control lists (ACL) and various VPN tunneling technologies. They continue with remote access types such as Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as well as Secure Shell (SSH).
episodes.title: Network Access Security

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don discuss some of the common security threats that network administrators are faced with and examine some of the methods used to defend against them.
episodes.title: Security Threats and Appliances

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don demonstrate the installation and management of a basic firewall. They run through various scenarios and demonstrate a typical configuration. If you would like to learn more about pfSense be sure to check out their website at http://pfsense.org
episodes.title: Configuring a Firewall
